snippet: Davis, Calif., obtained an armored vehicle from the Defense Department that the police chief called “perfect” for active shooter incidents. Then the City Council told the police to get rid of it.
abstract: City Council in Davis, Calif, is ordering Police Chief Landy Black to get rid of $700,000 armored car that was given to city by federal government; comes in response to uproar after use of such equipment by police in Ferguson, Mo; decision is raising concern among police officials statewide, and highlights fact that California has one of the nation's highest concentrations of surplus military equipment.
lead_paragraph: Davis, Calif., obtained an armored vehicle from the Defense Department that the police chief called “perfect” for active shooter incidents. Then the City Council told the police to get rid of it.

headline.main: Police Armored Vehicle Is Unwelcome in California College Town
headline.print_headline: Fit for Combat, but It’s No Match for a College Town
